dispositions.title: Socially Conscious
dispositions.definition: Takes responsibility for improving community wellbeing and notices where participation is uneven.
iCan: I can notice when voices or needs are missing in our community evidence.
I can plan an action that benefits people beyond my friendship group.

activities.title: Community Empathy Walk
objectives: Observe local civic assets and needs through a democratic lens
Gather qualitative evidence that will inform our civic action choices
steps: Take a guided walk around the school or local area using empathy-mapping prompts.
Capture photos/notes showing both healthy-democracy moments and friction points.
Return to class, sort findings into strengths/needs and identify emerging themes.
successCriteria: I can describe at least two community strengths and two needs with evidence.
I can propose one actionable improvement based on documented needs.

activities.title: Civic Feedback Studio
objectives: Provide constructive feedback on peers' civic action prototypes
Use community impact criteria to refine project decisions
steps: Set up stations with success criteria for impact, feasibility and ethics.
Teams share prototypes; peers leave warm/ cool feedback linked to criteria.
Teams synthesise feedback and document the changes they will make next.
successCriteria: I can reference community impact or justice when giving feedback.
I can explain how peer feedback improved our civic action plan.

dispositions.title: Discerning
dispositions.definition: Interrogates information, bias and perspective before acting.
iCan: I can test the reliability of sources and explain my reasoning.
I can compare perspectives to avoid single-story thinking.

activities.title: Evidence Audit Protocol
objectives: Evaluate the reliability and bias of sources gathered for our inquiry
Prioritise evidence that offers balanced perspectives
steps: Teams list every source currently in use for the project.
Apply a reliability rubric (authorship, evidence, currency, bias) to rate each source.
Decide keep/replace actions and record justification in the inquiry log.
successCriteria: I can justify why a source is trustworthy or biased using rubric language.
I can show how our final evidence set balances multiple perspectives.

activities.title: Perspective Fishbowl
objectives: Analyse how different stakeholders view a democratic issue
Practise questioning that surfaces assumptions and evidence
steps: Assign stakeholder roles with briefing cards that include values and evidence snippets.
Inner circle conducts a short dialogue while outer circle tracks bias/evidence cues.
Swap roles and debrief: what shifted in understanding and what evidence was compelling?
successCriteria: I can ask questions that clarify evidence or values driving a perspective.
I can summarise two contrasting perspectives without adding judgement.

dispositions.title: Principled
dispositions.definition: Acts with integrity, honours rights and upholds fairness during civic participation.
iCan: I can link my civic values to democratic principles like equity and accountability.
I can make choices that keep advocacy respectful and lawful.

activities.title: Values & Boundaries Workshop
objectives: Clarify personal civic values and connect them to democratic principles
Establish non-negotiables for respectful group advocacy
steps: Students map personal values to principles such as fairness, participation and accountability.
Analyse case studies where activism crossed a line; identify what went wrong.
Draft a team charter outlining norms and boundaries for ethical participation.
successCriteria: I can connect a personal value to a democratic principle we studied.
I can state boundaries that keep our advocacy respectful and inclusive.

activities.title: Rights in Action Clinic
objectives: Apply legal rights and responsibilities to authentic civic scenarios
Design principled responses that respect due process
steps: Groups analyse scenario cards (protest permits, online speech, policing encounters).
Use fact sheets to identify the rights, responsibilities and limits involved.
Plan a response that upholds fairness for all parties and present to the class gallery.
successCriteria: I can cite the specific right or responsibility relevant to a scenario.
I can design an action that upholds fairness for everyone impacted.
